title: Synthetic Recap
body:
EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — In an era defined by high-flying offense, the Cleveland Cavaliers authored a masterpiece of defensive brutality, dismantling the New Jersey Nets 84-62 in a 1997 contest that was less a basketball game and more a systematic shutdown.

From the opening tip, the Cavaliers imposed their will, holding the Nets to a paltry 62 points—a number that would be respectable for a single half in today’s game. The Cavs’ defense was a vise, tightening with each possession and suffocating any rhythm New Jersey attempted to establish. The Nets’ leading scorers, Kendall Gill and Kerry Kittles, were held to a combined 27 points, a testament to the swarming, relentless pressure applied by Cleveland.

The victory was a collective triumph of grit over glamour. While no single Cavalier dominated the scoring sheet, the balance was telling. Chris Mills provided a steadying hand with a team-high 16 points, while Shawn Kemp anchored the interior with 13 points and a game-high 12 rebounds. The Cavaliers’ defense was the true star of the night, transforming the contest into a grind-it-out affair perfectly suited to their physical style.

For the Nets, the final score was an embarrassing indictment of their offensive execution. The 62-point total stands as a stark reminder of a night where every shot was contested, every pass was challenged, and the basket seemed to shrink by the minute.

In the record books, this game will be remembered not for a singular historic performance, but for a throwback, defensive clinic. The Cleveland Cavaliers didn’t just win a game; they delivered a statement written in sweat and steel, proving that a dominant defense can still silence an arena and overwhelm an opponent.
